hints: This scientific principle changed how we understand motion
Named after an English physicist and mathematician
Also known as the Law of Inertia
States that objects at rest stay at rest unless acted upon by force
F = ma is related, but this is specifically about objects in motion or at rest
This Renaissance master created some of the world's most famous paintings
Born in Italy in the 15th century
Known for both art and scientific inventions
Painted the Mona Lisa
Also painted The Last Supper
This process is essential for life on Earth
Involves converting light energy into chemical energy
Plants use this to create food from sunlight
Produces oxygen as a byproduct
Uses chlorophyll and occurs mainly in leaves
This is the highest point on Earth
Located in the Himalayas
Sits on the border between Nepal and Tibet
Many climbers attempt to reach its summit each year
Also known as Sagarmatha in Nepali
This global conflict lasted from 1939 to 1945
Involved most of the world's nations
Featured the Holocaust and atomic bomb usage
Axis powers fought against Allied powers
Ended with Germany and Japan's surrender
This scientist is often called the Father of Relativity
He developed the famous equation E=mc²
He won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921
His wild hair and mustache made him instantly recognizable
He was born in Germany but later became an American citizen
This ancient structure stretches for thousands of miles
It was built to protect against invasions from the north
Construction began in the 7th century BC
It is visible from space (though this is a myth)
It winds through deserts, grasslands, and mountains in Asia
This English playwright is considered the greatest writer in the English language
He wrote 39 plays and 154 sonnets
His works include tragedies, comedies, and histories
He created characters like Hamlet, Romeo, and Juliet
He lived from 1564 to 1616 in Stratford-upon-Avon
This "unsinkable" ship sank on its maiden voyage in 1912
It hit an iceberg in the North Atlantic Ocean
Over 1,500 people died in the disaster
It was traveling from Southampton to New York City
James Cameron made a famous movie about this tragedy
This is the largest planet in our solar system
It is a gas giant with no solid surface
It has a Great Red Spot that is actually a giant storm
It has over 80 known moons
Its four largest moons were discovered by Galileo
This molecule carries genetic information in all living things
It has a double helix structure
Watson, Crick, and Franklin were key in discovering its structure
It stands for deoxyribonucleic acid
It is made up of four bases: A, T, G, and C
This famous painting hangs in the Louvre Museum in Paris
It was painted by Leonardo da Vinci
The subject has a mysterious smile
It was stolen in 1911 but recovered two years later
The subject is believed to be Lisa Gherardini
This element makes up about 21% of Earth's atmosphere
All animals need this to breathe and survive
Its chemical symbol is O
It has an atomic number of 8
Plants produce this during photosynthesis
This British band formed in Liverpool in 1960
They were known as the Fab Four
Their members included John, Paul, George, and Ringo
They had hits like "Hey Jude" and "Let It Be"
They appeared on The Ed Sullivan Show in 1964
This is the longest river in South America
It flows through the world's largest rainforest
It empties into the Atlantic Ocean
It has over 1,100 tributaries
It flows through Brazil, Peru, Colombia, and other countries
This organelle is often called the powerhouse of the cell
It produces ATP, the cell's energy currency
It has its own DNA separate from the cell nucleus
It is believed to have evolved from ancient bacteria
Muscle cells contain many of these due to high energy needs
This Dutch post-impressionist painter cut off his own ear
He only sold one painting during his lifetime
His works include "Starry Night" and "Sunflowers"
He suffered from mental illness and died at age 37
His brother Theo supported him financially throughout his life
This antibiotic was discovered accidentally in 1928
It was found growing as mold in a petri dish
Alexander Fleming discovered it
It saved millions of lives during World War II
It comes from a type of fungus called Penicillium
This is the largest hot desert in the world
It covers much of North Africa
It is roughly the size of the United States
Its name means "desert" in Arabic
It experiences extreme temperature differences between day and night
This naturalist developed the theory of evolution
He sailed on the HMS Beagle to the Galápagos Islands
He wrote "On the Origin of Species"
His theory explains how species change over time
He proposed the concept of natural selection
This structure divided a major European city from 1961 to 1989
It separated East and West during the Cold War
Ronald Reagan famously said "Tear down this wall!"
Its fall marked the beginning of German reunification
It was built overnight to prevent people from escaping to the West
This was the last active pharaoh of ancient Egypt
She had relationships with Julius Caesar and Mark Antony
She spoke nine languages and was highly educated
She died by snake bite (according to legend)
Elizabeth Taylor famously portrayed her in a 1963 film
This is the largest ocean on Earth
It covers about one-third of the planet's surface
It contains the Mariana Trench, the deepest point on Earth
It separates Asia and Australia from the Americas
Its name means "peaceful" in Latin
This composer was a child prodigy who started composing at age 5
He lived from 1756 to 1791
He composed over 600 works in his short life
His full name was Wolfgang Amadeus
He wrote famous operas like "The Magic Flute" and "Don Giovanni"
This cosmic object has gravity so strong that nothing can escape it
Not even light can escape from beyond its event horizon
Einstein's theory of relativity predicted their existence
The first image of one was captured in 2019
They form when massive stars collapse at the end of their lives
This novel was written by F. Scott Fitzgerald
It's set in the Jazz Age of the 1920s
The story is narrated by Nick Carraway
It features the mysterious millionaire Jay Gatsby
The green light at the end of Daisy's dock is a famous symbol
This ancient city is located high in the Andes Mountains
It was built by the Inca civilization in the 15th century
It's often called the "Lost City of the Incas"
It was rediscovered by Hiram Bingham in 1911
It's located in modern-day Peru
This muscular organ pumps blood throughout the body
It has four chambers: two atria and two ventricles
It beats about 100,000 times per day
It's roughly the size of a clenched fist
It's located slightly left of center in the chest
This cultural movement began in Italy in the 14th century
It marked the transition from medieval to modern times
It was characterized by renewed interest in art, science, and learning
Famous figures include Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo
The name means "rebirth" in French
This monument was a gift from France to the United States
It stands on an island in New York Harbor
It was designed by Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi
It holds a torch in one hand and a tablet in the other
It was dedicated in 1886 and symbolizes freedom and democracy
This fundamental force attracts objects with mass toward each other
Sir Isaac Newton described it after observing a falling apple
Einstein later described it as the curvature of spacetime
It keeps planets in orbit around the sun
It's the weakest of the four fundamental forces
These ancient structures are among the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World
They were built as tombs for Egyptian pharaohs
The largest was built for Pharaoh Khufu
They are located near Cairo, Egypt
The Great Sphinx guards these monuments
This composer continued to write music even after losing his hearing
He composed nine symphonies
His most famous piece might be "Ode to Joy"
He lived from 1770 to 1827
His first name was Ludwig van
This body system controls and coordinates all body functions
It consists of the brain, spinal cord, and nerves
It processes information and sends signals throughout the body
Neurons are the basic cells of this system
It can be divided into central and peripheral parts
This is Shakespeare's longest play
The protagonist is the Prince of Denmark
Features the famous soliloquy "To be or not to be"
The main character seeks revenge for his father's murder
Contains the play-within-a-play scene
This global network connects billions of devices worldwide
It originated from ARPANET in the 1960s
Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web on this
It uses protocols like HTTP, TCP/IP, and DNS
Social media, email, and websites all use this infrastructure
This scientist was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize
She discovered the elements polonium and radium
She was born in Poland but worked in France
She won Nobel Prizes in both Physics and Chemistry
She died from radiation exposure due to her research
This celestial body causes tides on Earth
It's about 238,900 miles from Earth
Apollo 11 was the first mission to land here
It has phases: new, waxing, full, and waning
Neil Armstrong was the first human to walk on it
This conflict lasted from 1861 to 1865
It was fought between the Union and the Confederacy
Abraham Lincoln was president during this war
It began with the attack on Fort Sumter
It ended slavery in the United States
This Spanish artist co-founded the Cubist movement
He painted "Guernica" depicting the horrors of war
His Blue Period featured predominantly blue paintings
He lived from 1881 to 1973
His full name was Pablo Diego José Francisco de Paula Juan Nepomuceno
This is the smallest and shallowest ocean
It surrounds the North Pole
It's mostly covered by sea ice year-round
Polar bears live around its edges
Climate change is rapidly affecting this ocean
These medicines fight bacterial infections
Penicillin was the first widely used one
They don't work against viral infections
Overuse can lead to resistance
Alexander Fleming discovered the first one by accident
This revolution began in 1789
It overthrew the monarchy in France
Marie Antoinette was executed during this period
The slogan was "Liberty, Equality, Fraternity"
It led to the rise of Napoleon Bonaparte
This form of energy powers most modern devices
Benjamin Franklin studied it with kites and keys
It flows through conductors like copper wire
Lightning is a natural form of this phenomenon
It can be generated by moving magnets near coils
This is traditionally considered the longest river in the world
It flows through Egypt and several other African countries
Ancient Egyptian civilization developed along its banks
It floods annually, depositing fertile soil
The Aswan High Dam was built to control its flow
These prehistoric reptiles dominated Earth for millions of years
They went extinct about 66 million years ago
Some evolved into modern birds
T. Rex and Triceratops are famous examples
Their fossils help us understand ancient life
This body system defends against diseases and infections
White blood cells are its main soldiers
It can remember previous infections for faster response
Vaccines train this system to recognize threats
It includes organs like the spleen and lymph nodes
This is Shakespeare's most famous tragedy about young love
It features two feuding families in Verona
The Montagues and Capulets are the warring houses
The protagonists die in the end
Friar Lawrence secretly marries the couple
This is the coldest and windiest continent
It's almost entirely covered by ice
No permanent human residents live here
It contains about 70% of the world's fresh water
Research stations from many countries operate here
This chart organizes all known chemical elements
Dmitri Mendeleev created the first version
Elements are arranged by atomic number
It predicts properties of undiscovered elements
Hydrogen is the first element on this table
This process allows plants to make food from sunlight
It converts carbon dioxide and water into glucose
Chlorophyll captures light energy for this process
Oxygen is released as a byproduct
It mainly occurs in plant leaves
This cultural rebirth began in 14th century Italy
It marked the end of the Middle Ages
Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo were key figures
It emphasized humanism and classical learning
The printing press helped spread its ideas
These medical preparations prevent infectious diseases
Edward Jenner developed the first one for smallpox
They work by training the immune system
They contain weakened or dead pathogens
They have eliminated or reduced many deadly diseases
This theory explains the origin of the universe
It suggests the universe began as a singularity
The universe has been expanding ever since
Cosmic microwave background radiation supports this theory
It occurred approximately 13.8 billion years ago
This musical genre originated in New Orleans
It features improvisation and complex rhythms
Louis Armstrong was one of its pioneers
The Harlem Renaissance helped popularize it
It influenced many other musical styles
